Dictionary Class

The Dictionary class is a class for handling dictionary arrays.

Dictionary arrays are also called associative arrays; they are objects that hold multiple pairs of names and their associated values.
Like arrays, they are accessed using the [ ] (indirect reference) operator, but instead of indices, strings are used as names. If the name is valid as an identifier, the . (direct reference) operator can also be used.
Additionally, referencing a name that does not exist results in void.
To delete an element, use the delete operator.

Example:
    var d=new Dictionary();
    d["sat"] = 1; // Same as d.sat = 1
    d["sun"] = 2; // Same as d.sun = 2
    d["mon"] = 3; // Same as d.mon = 3
    d["name"] ="value!"; // Same as d.name = "value!"
    d["continue"] = 4; // continue is not an identifier, but OK
    d.continue = 4; // Error because continue is not an identifier

    var sat = d["sat"]; // 1 is assigned
    var none = d["none"]; // void is assigned

    delete d.sat; // Delete sat
    delete d["continue"]; // Delete continue

Inline Dictionary Arrays

Using %[ ], you can describe a Dictionary class object directly within an expression. Enumerate the expressions for the initial elements, separating element names => element values with commas. For example, if you write
    var dic = %["a" => 1, "b" => 2, "c" => 3];
, a reference to a Dictionary class object with element name and value pairs "a":1, "b":2, and "c":3 will be assigned to dic.
Internally, => is exactly the same as a comma, but => can be used for better readability (same as in Perl).

Accessing Dictionary Class Methods

Dictionary class objects do not have any members when they are first created.
For example, if you try to use the assign method by writing dict.assign(src) on a Dictionary class object dict, it will result in an error because dict does not have a method named assign.
Therefore, use the incontextof operator to execute methods that belong directly to the Dictionary class, using the target Dictionary class object as the context.

Example:
    var a = %[];
    var b = %[];
    (Dictionary.assign incontextof a)(b); // Copy b to a
    (Dictionary.clear incontextof b)(); // Clear the contents of b

saveStruct

saveStruct outputs structured data to a file.
Please refer to the same method in the Array Class.

assign

The assign method copies a dictionary array.

Syntax : assign(<source dictionary array>, <whether to clear contents=true>)
Copies the contents of another dictionary array specified by the argument.
If "whether to clear contents" is false, the contents of the copy destination (the object executing the method) are not cleared, and the contents of the source dictionary array are overwritten. If a member with the same name as the source dictionary array exists in the destination dictionary array, the destination is overwritten with the source's content.

If an array (Array class object) is specified as the source, it is assumed that the array contains elements that should become members of this dictionary array in the order of name and value, and the contents of that array are copied into this dictionary array.

assignStruct

The assignStruct method copies a dictionary array.

Syntax : assignStruct(<source dictionary array>)
Copies the contents of another dictionary array specified by the argument.
Unlike the assign method, if there are arrays or dictionary arrays among the members, their contents are also copied recursively (in the case of the assign method, only the references are copied).

clear

The clear method clears all contents of the dictionary array.
